title: CI: the main Linux matrix build sometimes creates illegal instructions
body:
*Original issue*: https://gitlab.com/lfortran/lfortran/-/issues/747

An example:
```
FAILED: src/runtime/lfortran_intrinsic_builtin.mod /home/runner/work/lfortran/lfortran/lfortran-0.16.0-262-g250fa5e1a/test-bld/src/runtime/lfortran_intrinsic_builtin.mod 
cd /home/runner/work/lfortran/lfortran/lfortran-0.16.0-262-g250fa5e1a/test-bld/src/runtime && /home/runner/work/lfortran/lfortran/lfortran-0.16.0-262-g250fa5e1a/test-bld/src/bin/lfortran --backend=cpp -c /home/runner/work/lfortran/lfortran/lfortran-0.16.0-262-g250fa5e1a/src/bin/../runtime/builtin/lfortran_intrinsic_builtin.f90 -o lfortran_intrinsic_builtin.o
Illegal instruction (core dumped)
```
This is typically caused by the fact that we are compiling with `-march=native`, and Clang or GCC compiles for the architecture it thinks it is running on, but the virtual image is lying about its CPU, and so it fails to execute the compiled code with "Illegal instruction (core dumped)".
